Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation2: The project is still in exploratory discussions, and alternative approaches can be proposed later
Story: Every Sunday evening, I call my stepdad and mom, just like I promised when I moved out for my engineering job. They look forward to these calls, and I know it means a lot to them—especially since I’m not their biological child, and I want to show I care. Tonight, though, my mind is tangled in the project at work. We’re in the early stages, and my manager expects me to brainstorm new technical solutions before tomorrow’s meeting. I keep glancing at my phone, torn. If I call home, I’ll have to set aside the time and energy to really listen and share, not just go through the motions. But if I focus on work, I might finally crack the idea that’s been eluding me all weekend. I feel the weight of both roles pressing in—my parents’ gentle expectation for connection, and my team’s unspoken demand for innovation. My heart aches with guilt and anxiety as I stare at my phone, caught between the family I chose and the career I’m building.
